fields.label_text:
1. CUP & COVER The Painter & Stainers' Cup
Silver set with semi precious stones and enamel
London, 1900-01
Mark of W Poyser
Designed by C R Ashbee (1863-1942)
Ashbee regarded the study of 17th century English and Continental goldsmiths' work as an essential part of his guildsmen's programme of self education.  Here, his design is based on English 17th century steeple cups but Ashbee has made a very contemporary and subtle restatement of the original design.

Ashbee occasionally went outside the Guild for the execution of his designs.  His reasons for selecting  Poyser in this instance remains unclear for he cannot be traced in the Ashbee papers or in the list of Guild workers given in Ashbee's Craftsmanship in Competitive Industry 1908.  The cup was commissioned in 1900 by Harris Heal to commemorate his term of office as Master of the Painters and Stainers Company.
M.106&a-1966

fields.name: Kershaw Dinner
fields.venue: Worshipful Company of Painter Stainers, Painters' Hall

fields.physical_description:
Steeple cup and cover.  Silver, gilt interior with enamel decoration and set with sic turquoises.

The deep bowl with an everted rim, embossed with a frieze of tulips, the petals turned back to reveal a cluster of stamens.  Plain baluster stem with openwork brackets in the form of leaves and fruits;  the stem becomes an inverted bell shape at the base.  Circular stepped and domed base embossed with leaves and flowers similar to those on the body.

The stepped and domed cover iscribed round the rim; the embossed decoration is of inverted tulips and leaves.  In the centre, a shaped form supportys a plate with a slightly circular cover, enamelled in turquoise and green, five embossed panels round the base of the fumal, each set with a cabochon turquoise.  Three scrolling brackets at the edge of the enamelled dome each support four silver wires, which are woven into a steeple form, surmounted by a flower in which is set a cabochon turquoise.
fields.title: The ^Painter-Stainer’s Cup
fields.materials_techniques: Silver set with semi-precious stones and enamelled decoration
fields.label:
1. CUP & COVER The Painter & Stainers' Cup
Silver set with semi precious stones and enamel
London, 1900-01
Mark of W Poyser
Designed by C R Ashbee (1863-1942)
Ashbee regarded the study of 17th century English and Continental goldsmiths' work as an essential part of his guildsmen's programme of self education.  Here, his design is based on English 17th century steeple cups but Ashbee has made a very contemporary and subtle restatement of the original design.

Ashbee occasionally went outside the Guild for the execution of his designs.  His reasons for selecting  Poyser in this instance remains unclear for he cannot be traced in the Ashbee papers or in the list of Guild workers given in Ashbee's Craftsmanship in Competitive Industry 1908.  The cup was commissioned in 1900 by Harris Heal to commemorate his term of office as Master of the Painters and Stainers Company.
M.106&a-1966 [18/02/2000]
fields.marks:
The rim of the bowl bears the inscription in embossed letters:  THE GIFT / OF HARRIS / HEAL MASTER 1892 1893
 The stepped and domed cover inscribed around the rim: AMOR / ET / OBEDIENTA  love and obdience
 London hallmarks for 1900-01, maker’s mark for W. Poyser
fields.public_access_description:
Harris Heal commissioned this silver cup in 1900 to commemorate his term of office as Master of the Painter-Stainers’ Company in the City of London. Charles Robert Ashbee (1863-1942) based his design for it on English steeple cups made in the period 1600-1700. These tall standing cups had domed covers with tall finials in the form of three- or four-sided pyramid-shaped ‘steeples’. 

Here you can see how Ashbee has subtly reworked the traditional design. He has made a delicate wirework steeple finial and used the combination of restrained enamelled decoration and semi-precious stones associated with Arts and Crafts silverware. The silver surface has a soft sheen and has been finished with a round-faced planishing hammer. 

Ashbee regarded the study of the work of 17th-century English and Continental goldsmiths as an essential part of the programme of self-education for members of his Guild of Handicafts. Founded in the East End of London in 1888, the Guild followed the concept of the medieval workshop and promoted traditional handicraft skills that were passed from master to apprentice.

Ashbee occasionally went outside the Guild for the execution of his designs. For this piece he chose W. Poyser for reasons that remain unclear.
fields.exhibition_history:
The Silver Galleries (Victoria and Albert Museum)
Kershaw Dinner (Worshipful Company of Painter Stainers, Painters' Hall 04/07/2007-04/07/2007)

C.R. Ashbee <u>Modern English Silverwork</u>, London 1909, new edition ed. Shirley Bury, London, 1974
fields.history_note:
Ashbee regarded the study of 17th century English and Continental goldsmiths' work as an essential part of his guildsmen's programme of self education.  Here, his design is based on English 17th century steeple cups but Ashbee has made a very contemporary and subtle restatement of the original design.

Ashbee occasionally went outside the Guild for the execution of his designs.  His reasons for selecting  Poyser in this instance remains unclear for he cannot be traced in the Ashbee papers or in the list of Guild workers given in Ashbee's Craftsmanship in Competitive Industry 1908.  The cup and cover was commissioned in 1900 by Harris Heal to commemorate his term of office as Master of the Painters and Stainers Company in 1900.

Kershaw Dinner RF.2007/190
fields.historical_context_note:
EDWARDIAN SILVER

Despite relentless commercial pressures and a conservative public which favoured historicist revivals, innovations did emerge in European silverware in the early years of the 20th century, prior to the First World War.  The cup and cover (1909-10) by Child & Child of Thurloe Place, South Kensington, in a revived, German Renaissance manner illustrates the prevailing mainstream taste for historicism while the Painter and Stainers’ Cup designed by C.R. Ashbee for Harris Heal (1900-01) is a very contemporary and subtle restatement of a 17th century design and epitomises the essence of the British Arts and Crafts movement.  

By 1900, Ashbee and his Guild of Handicraft had a achieved a stylistic maturity.  For a while the Guild even showed a modest profit but events were moving swiftly.  In the 1890s the work produced by the Guild struck a fresh and original note.  By the 1900s, Ashbee was to witness others adapting his ideas and extending them further.  The workshops of Henry Wilson, Nelson Dawson and Edward Spencer of the Artificer’s Guild, Omar Ramsden and in Denmark,  Michelsen and Georg Jensen began to produce work that was richer and more self assured than the austere, products of the Guild of Handicraft.  These firms successfully popularised the Arts and Crafts philosophy and occasionally incorporated Art Nouveau tendencies.  The retailer A.L. Liberty of Regent Street with his Cymric range of silver and jewellery was the amongst the most successful and all remained commercially viable long after the demise of the Guild in 1908.

(Graphic panel:  the Silver Galleries)
